Packets of Purpose is a food donation drive in which people volunteer to craft packets of ration supplies for the underprivileged. We do not ask for donations from anyone, just their time - to come together as a community and spend time physically working for this cause. 

The act of working hands-on for an extended period strengthens the virtue of giving back to society. Volunteers work together to distribute these packets in underprivileged areas, engaging with the community and reinforcing the importance of giving back. 

Our next donation drive is on Sunday, April 28, 2024 in Gurgaon. People interested in volunteering can join this chat app group (serious participants only): https://chat.whatsapp.com/GzhK5FABOHAHLV097gP5zq
If you won't be able to participate yourself, consider forwarding the message to relevant people (serious participantsÂ only).

sender: Mohammad Shoaib Sr. HRBP AQ Infratech
message:
Dear HR Fraternity,

I need your inputs or instances on this matter:

1. If in an NGO setup or in the social development sector, PMS (Performance Management System) is still being done either on hard copy or on the basis of an Excel sheet, is there any harm in using an Excel-based formula sheet for the PMS process?

2. What should be done in the organization if the management prefers to continue using hard copies due to older thoughts? Management believes that Excel files can be edited at any time, but what are the disadvantages of using Excel for PMS? As an HR professional, what should be your stance on hard copy versus Excel sheet-based PMS forms? Which one is better?

3. What should an organization do if it is unable to allocate funds for a dedicated PMS platform due to reliance on donor funding and current financial constraints? Should it continue using hard copy forms or implement Excel-based formula sheets? Which one is better?

Regards
Shoaib
Garima Srivastava Asst Manager TA PocketFM requested to join.
Self Community added Garima Srivastava Asst Manager TA PocketFM
Self Community added Saiyam Seth Corporate HR Jaquar
Let me know if I can be of help; I work in the social sector

Hii All,

Good Morning

This is Saiyam Seth, I currently work as Corporate HR at Jaquar and am based in Gurugram, Haryana.

Glad to be a part of this group.

My 2 cents!

Don't look at this from any other lens except whether this is really important for an NGO. 
Number of employees matter as well.

There is no harm using anything. When you don't have funding, it will only become a burden for the NGO to pick up these costs & also explain to investors that we did this for our ease. While the entire concept of running an NGO is ideally to help work towards public or social welfare & such costs can be considered unnecessary unless it hampers the operating of an NGO vs a people issue. 

Yo move to excel, first find out what are their objections & handle those. Example - if they say that data can be altered in Google sheets you can talk about Google forms importing data into a Gsheet where only the CEO will have edit access. You can create many rules to ensure data cannot be altered as it is a read only sheet. 

Find out other objections & then do your research (or seek the help of other experts in groups like this) so that you are well equipped to handle all objections & build confidence. 

Hope this helps ğŸ™

Interesting.  Kudos to this NGO that they are doing PMS in the first step. Here are my views for the stated issues by you: 

- You can use formulae in excel for PMS.  I don't see any threat. 
- Google excel sheets has different access like viewer, commenter, owner which restricts the edit access to the sheet. All the logs are available to see , so even if any change is done, owner of sheet can detect it. These sheets can be password protected as well to make  it secure. Data is safe. But with excels you can't analyse, compare data which is required in PMS.
- Open source excel like libre office is free. You can explore it. I was also testing some open-source PMS products, can share my inputs. ğŸ‘ <This message was edited>

sender: Shiva Madgula AVP HR Advantum Health
message:
Dependa on number employees for review. 

Second, *awareness is key* - I did face this in ana mech-IT firm way back 2008, *irrespective of usage, develop a dashboard with sample PMS reviews, ratings and data* present it to management. And alao show them *Protection feature in Excel*.

How effectively we can use data to ake decisions. Things will slowly change.

sender: Anjali Sathya TA Manager CADeploy Engineering
message: Sure

If I were in this situation, my first step would be to have an open conversation with the recruiter to understand the reasons behind the salary constraints and explore whether thereâ€™s any room for negotiation. If the role offers significant non-monetary benefits that align with my long-term career goals, I might consider accepting the offer. However, if the salary reduction is too steep and doesnâ€™t compensate for the other aspects of the job, I would likely decline the offer politely and continue searching for opportunities that better align with my financial and professional needs.

*Cover letter for job application for the post of judge*

By Amrit Kaal Mishra, The Leaflet, September 10, 2024
https://theleaflet.in/cover-letter-for-job-application-for-the-post-of-judge/

A day after the Delhi High Court was reported as inviting courtroom humour for publication on its website, Amrit Kaal Mishra applies for the job of a judge. His cover letter covers all bases but soars high in humorous skies for a vocation weighed down by gravitas.

Respected Your Honour,

I have always wanted to be a judge. Ever since I was a child, people have told me I have everything it takes to make a great judge.

Initially, I was not inclined to believe them. But there were signs, right from the beginning. My very date of birth, for instance, saw multiple adjournments. When I was finally born, it was 27 days after my due date, and everyone said waiting for me to get out of my Mommyâ€™s tummy was like waiting for a case to be heard.

The next sign, which manifested itself when I was a toddler, was my favourite toyâ€” a wooden hammer. While my own memories do not extend so far back into my early childhood, people tell me I liked nothing more than to keep banging on every surface with the hammer, screaming, â€œOrder, order!â€ or â€œAayega toh!â€

When I was 10, we moved to a farm. The farm had a stable. The stable had a horse. One day the horse escaped. I was just a kid but I had the presence of mind to lock the stable door after the horse had bolted. Everyone praised me for doing the right thing, especially when it was too late to make a difference. Following this success, I made it into a habit.

Last week, for instance, I was umpiring a tennis match between two teenagers in a local tournament. A wrong call from me on a crucial point caused one of the teenagers to lose the set and subsequently the match and the tournament.

I could have corrected my mistake immediately when everyone, including the spectators, the player concerned, and even his opponent pointed out that the ball was out. But I stuck to my guns.

However, once the match was over, I informed the losing player that I could grant him five match points in some other tournament. â€œNo thanks,â€ he said, then added, â€œYou should become a judge.â€

Even he could see that my talent was getting wasted in judging line calls when they could be put to better use denying bail.

You may have noted from my CV that in school, right from Class 1 all the way to Class 12, I have sat on benches of varying sizesâ€” two-student, five-student and nine-student benches; and sometimes I even managed to squeeze in with 14 students on one bench.

I believe this diversity of bench experience would make me an automatic choice when Your Honour constitutes Constitution Benches of whatever size.

You would be pleased to note that I love my summer vacations, and no matter how much holiday homework was given by the class teacher, I did not violate the sanctity of my vacation by doing studies at a vacation desk.

I am also hyper-allergic to the slightest note of contempt in anyoneâ€™s voice. Once my Class 11 maths teacher told me I would not understand trigonometry in a thousand years.

Although her observation was objectively valid, the note of contempt in her subjective voice made me complain to the headmaster who issued her a show cause noticeâ€” my earliest brush with a contempt notice, and yet another sign I was destined for judicial glory.

To get rid of anti-national topics like calculus, I switched from science to arts in Class 12 and became very good at making things with paper, scissors and cello tape. As you would expect, I became a whiz at making sealed coversâ€” a hallowed tool of justice delivery developed indigenously in India.

After school, while my classmates chose to go to college, I did notâ€” I went to a collegium instead. And there I learned the important lesson that satisfying the collective conscience of the nation is more important than upholding the Constitution.

I became a keen observer and an excellent speaker. These two capabilities would enable me to deliver sharp oral observations on constitutional morality in the courtroom and insightful lectures on judicial principles at the Oxford debating room, thereby liberating me from the burden of having to uphold those principles when I pass Orders.

I am also good at computers and carpentry. So I can help the judiciary with stuff like digitisation, and if anyone finds a bench uncomfortable, I can fix it pronto.

In conclusion, let me say that as a born generalist, I am constantly in agreement with any General, be it a Solicitor or Attorney, and appreciate the eternal truth that power trumps justice, and executive power executes justice.

Thank you for your kind consideration and look forward to sharing a bench with you soon.

sender: Anjali Sathya TA Manager CADeploy Engineering
message:
A Recruiterâ€™s Eye-Opener: Time for Change in Interviews

I recently had a conversation with a recruiter that shed light on some pressing issues in the interview process. 
 
As someone with a recruiting background, I found myself juggling multiple interviews in a day. During one scheduled interview at a well-known MNC, I forgot to bring my resume, despite having shared my updated version via email. When I asked for a copy on-site, the company remarked, "A first impression is everything." The consultancy added, "We can understand this for tech candidates, but why didnâ€™t you carry yours?" This made me reflect on several key points:

1.Â Unequal Support: Why do tech candidates receive more help than non-tech ones? All candidates deserve equal assistance.

2.Â Long Wait Times: Waiting for hours is common, even for managerial roles. Is this really necessary, or is only way to test of patience of job seekers?

3.Â Candidate Experience: Many articles say candidates should be treated like customers. Itâ€™s time we put this into practice.

4.Â Outdated Mindsets: Many hiring practices still feel stuck in the past, despite advancements in technology.

5.Â Disparity Between Fields: The pay gap between tech and non-tech roles shouldnâ€™t extend to how candidates are treated.

6.Â First Impressions: First impressions matter. Companies must show respect for candidatesâ€™ time and effort.

7.Â Performance vs. Communication: Just because someone speaks well doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™ll perform well. True abilities shine through when the actual tasks are assigned.

8.Â Value of Language: Why is jargon prioritized over language proficiency in interviews?

This conversation reminded me that candidates, regardless of their field, deserve respect and professionalism. If a company doesnâ€™t value your time, itâ€™s worth considering other options.

Letâ€™s advocate for change in how candidates are treated during the hiring process. What do you think?

sender: Sunit Desai Sr. Manager People Experience CashFlo
message: When I was with Dream11, we had this 5 days continuous leave called as Unplugged, for all employees. Unplugged meant literally unplugging that specific employee from all work-related channels and communications. Even their work email and slack used to get deactivated during this time, so they can't work while they are on unplugged. There was a heavy fine for the employee if he contacted anyone for any work related issue, and vice versa for anyone disturbing that employee with regards to work. This policy had two benefits, one was that the employee taking unplugged would spend complete time with family and for the company it was a time to test their systems and process, and their dependency on a specific individual. For example if a senior person is not contactable for entire 1 week, then how well equiped is the team, to work in his or her absence.
This is really great!

sender: Sunit Desai Sr. Manager People Experience CashFlo
message:
We did one more unique thing by differentiating employee referrals into two categories: 1). Responsible, and 2). Irresponsible referrals. 

A responsible referral was someone who the employee knew personally and could vouch for the person and his or her performance and also the role this person can fit in. Whereas an irresponsible referral is someone you have sourced from LinkedIn or any other source but don't know personally and are not sure if they would perfectly fit in a specific role or not. 

The rewards for responsible referral were much higher, whereas for irresponsible hire, were much lesser. 
This policy helped us to counter the random referrals that were shared by employees, responding to which was getting difficult for the HR team. Responsible referrals were treated as a priority, and sharing updates on it was mandatory for HR team, whereas the same was not applicable for Irresponsible referrals.
Another great idea thanks!
Good that you were getting so many referrals!
How would you identify the difference and what is the difference in the reward value?

sender: Sunit Desai Sr. Manager People Experience CashFlo
message: So the rewards for responsible referral were significantly higher like AirPods, laptops and for irresponsible referrals it was Amazon vouchers and we were running campaigns promoting responsible referrals

Hi all,

Need one suggestion. Suppose a person resigns on 27th April of the month and mutually decided with the ceo to service till 2nd May. Will she get the payment till 27th April in April month payroll and the rest in fnf or how is the process?
Entire pay in FnF. Companies generally dont change their payroll cycle for an individual.
The payroll cycle is 1-31st
And they payout on 3rd
Yeah, FnF only. Youâ€™re not required to pay separately till 27th.
Why is that as 27th the person resigned the notice period will only be in fnf right?
Pay for entire April month plus 2 days of May in FNF settlement. <This message was edited>

message: From Great Talent, i mean to say not only the Tech know how but speed as well

At Spyne, we have strictly capped salary jumps within 30%. Not looking for candidates who are chasing money alone.

Our focus is on merit, mindset, and long-term alignment. We want people who believe in building, growing with us, and creating impactâ€”not just optimizing comp.

Corrections, where justified, are made during structured appraisal cycles, and ESOPs are rewarded to those who demonstrate ownership and alignment with our values, ensuring long-term wealth creation.

sender: Shiv Jha Associate Director TA Zolo
message: Good for Singles
<Media omitted>

On a serious note though, it's true that as an HR leader, people's perception of you is your reality and I genuinely avoid hanging out with any one person (male or female) from another department so that people can openly come to me and tell me if they have a problem with anyone in the organization. 

You're always walking on a thin sheet of ice and covering up even the very perception of bias towards or against anyone is near impossible. To avoid that, I have even always trained my juniors to be friendly but never be close friends with anyone in the workplace. 

She summarises that well.

sender: Sukant Saxena Sr. Lead TA Leadsquared
message:
Sandwich method is actually proven to be confusing in many studies, because it lets the recipient focus on what they want to hear and not what the feedback giver is saying - and when fully received it becomes confusing on which side of the feedback did the giver actually meant more. 
- A lax recipient will hear that everything is good because they only hear the praise and encouragement, and pt of improvement a minor inconvenience they can think on later.
- â An overthinking, insecure person focuses wholly on the negative feedback and disregards positive encouragement and sentiment as false praise to guise the actual feedback. 

In reality the giver needs to have a deep relationship of trust with the recipient that they know the giver is coming from a point of care - the feedback itself doesnâ€™t land well without it.

I hate the sandwich method myself, because when I was young all my managers (from different fields of tech, analytics, HR) exploited this method without understanding the purpose of it (which is good in of itself).
